xocs:funding-list.xocs:funding-text: This work is supported by the Nanotechnology Center ( NANOTEC ), NSTDA , Ministry of Science and Technology , Thailand, through its program on Center of Excellence Network. PR thanks the Grant for International Research Integration: Chula Research Scholar, Ratchadapiseksomphot Endowment Fund of Chulalongkorn University .

organization.$: Program of Petrochemistry and Polymer Science
Program of Pharmaceutical Chemistry and Natural Products
Department of Food and Pharmaceutical Chemistry
Nanotec-CU Center of Excellence on Food and Agriculture

head.citation-title: A highly selective turn-on fluorescent sensor for glucosamine from amidoquinoline-napthalimide dyads
head.abstracts: © 2016 Elsevier B.V.Three amidoquinoline-naphthalimide dyads are designed and synthesized in 67–73% overall yields in 3 steps from commercially available starting materials. Compounds with unsubstituted and nitro naphthalimide (1 and 2) show excellent selective fluorescent responses towards glucosamine with the enhancement of fluorescence quantum yields by 14 folds. The determination of HOMO-LUMO levels by linear sweep voltammetry suggests that the sensing mechanism likely involves the inhibition of photo-induced electron transfer (PET) between the aminoquinoline and naphthalimide moieties by glucosamine. The association constants of 1.55×104 and 1.45×104 M−1, along with the glucosamine detection limits of 1.06 and 0.29 µM are determined for 1 and 2, respectively. The application of 2 as a fluorescent probe for real-time detection of cellular glucosamine at micromolar level in living Caco-2 cells is also demonstrated.

classification.classification-description: APPLIED MICROBIOLOGY AND BIOTECHNOLOGY; ANIMAL BIOTECHNOLOGY; Biosensors

grant-text.$: This work is supported by the Nanotechnology Center (NANOTEC), NSTDA, Ministry of Science and Technology, Thailand, through its program on Center of Excellence Network. PR thanks the Grant for International Research Integration: Chula Research Scholar, Ratchadapiseksomphot Endowment Fund of Chulalongkorn University.

coredata.dc:description: Three amidoquinoline-naphthalimide dyads are designed and synthesized in 67–73% overall yields in 3 steps from commercially available starting materials. Compounds with unsubstituted and nitro naphthalimide (1 and 2) show excellent selective fluorescent responses towards glucosamine with the enhancement of fluorescence quantum yields by 14 folds. The determination of HOMO-LUMO levels by linear sweep voltammetry suggests that the sensing mechanism likely involves the inhibition of photo-induced electron transfer (PET) between the aminoquinoline and naphthalimide moieties by glucosamine. The association constants of 1.55×104 and 1.45×104 M−1, along with the glucosamine detection limits of 1.06 and 0.29 µM are determined for 1 and 2, respectively. The application of 2 as a fluorescent probe for real-time detection of cellular glucosamine at micromolar level in living Caco-2 cells is also demonstrated.
coredata.dc:title: A highly selective turn-on fluorescent sensor for glucosamine from amidoquinoline-napthalimide dyads
